channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Ukraine Takes the Next Step in Its Hard-Fought Counteroffensive
item.description: After breaking through the first major line of Russian defenses around Robotyne, Ukraine appears to hold it securely enough to press on to the nearby village of Verbove.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Checking on the damage caused by a drone and missile attack in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: South Africa Fire: Fire in Johannesburg Kills at Least 74 People, Including a Dozen Children
item.description: An early-morning blaze tore through a five-story building that had become a sprawling, informal settlement, officials said. The cause was not known.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters at the scene of the deadly fire in Johannesburg early Thursday.

item.title: Why the Johannesburg Apartment Building Was a Firetrap
item.description: A visit and imagery of the five-story building show that it had a litany of major safety issues that made it vulnerable to a deadly fire.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby, Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon

item.title: An Obsolete German Tank Seeks a Second Life on Ukraine’s Front Lines
item.description: The Cold War-era Leopard 1A5 may be old, but it is still effective, Germany says. The country is now training Ukrainian troops to operate the weapons.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with a Leopard 1A5 tank at the German army’s Bundeswehr base in Klietz, Germany.

item.title: China’s Disinformation Fuels Anger Over Fukushima Water Release
item.description: By exaggerating the risks from Japan’s discharge of treated wastewater, Beijing hopes to cast Japan and its allies as conspirators in malfeasance, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and John Liu
item.media:description: A screen in Beijing showed Chinese state media coverage of a protest against Japan’s release of wastewater from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.

item.title: Resurgent Labour Party Sees Scotland as Springboard to Power
item.description: As the Scottish nationalists stumble, a by-election near Glasgow this fall will test support for the opposition Labour party ahead of Britain’s coming general election.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Emily Macinnes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scottish Labour supporters campaigned door-to-door in Blantyre, Scotland, in August.

item.title: Philippine Fire in Apparel Factory Kills at Least 15
item.description: Employees, the business owner and some of his relatives were among the dead at the shop near Manila. The cause of the blaze was unknown.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: The scene after a fire at a factory in Quezon City, the Philippines on Thursday.

item.title: More Than 100 Schools in England Ordered to Close Buildings Over Faulty Concrete
item.description: The news came just days before the start of the academic year for most children, even though critics say the risks have been known for some time.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of students at a school in London in January.

item.title: Rare Protests in Syria Summon Echoes of Arab Spring
item.description: After 12 years of conflict, anger over growing economic hardships has boiled over. Protesters are demanding the ouster of the authoritarian President Bashar al-Assad and an end to the war.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Suwayda24, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A demonstration on Tuesday in Sweida, the southern province of Syria where this wave of protests began. They have spread, even briefly touching Damascus, the capital.

item.title: U.K. Names Grant Shapps as New Defense Minister
item.description: Ben Wallace, a former soldier, championed the Ukrainians in their war against Russia. His successor, Grant Shapps, is best known for his political skills.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The newly appointed Defense Secretary Grant Shapps leaving No. 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.

item.title: Chile Searches for Its Disappeared, 50 Years After Coup
item.description: President Gabriel Boric authorized a new national search plan ahead of the 50th anniversary of the coup that toppled the government and led to the disappearance and killing of thousands.
item.dc:creator: Pascale Bonnefoy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Association of Relatives of the Disappeared
item.media:description: A commemoration in Santiago, Chile, in July for Chileans who were detained or went missing during the Pinochet dictatorship.

item.title: Pope Says a Strong U.S. Faction Offers a Backward, Narrow View of the Church
item.description: In unusually sharp remarks published this week, Pope Francis said some conservative American Catholics wrongly ignore much of the Church’s mission and reject the possibility of change.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Ruth Graham
item.category: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving for the weekly general audience in Paul VI hall at the Vatican on Tuesday.

item.title: For Greek Fires and Other Crises, E.U. Builds Emergency Force
item.description: The European Union deployed firefighters and equipment in what could be a preview of how it handles disasters linked to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Residents watching the fires in the Evros region of northeastern Greece last week. The country is at the frontier of Europe’s climate crisis, which unleashed intense heat waves and wildfires this summer.

item.title: U.S. Officials Have Visited China. Will Beijing Send Anyone?
item.description: Such visits could help convey Beijing’s interest in stabilizing ties with Washington. But China has been noncommittal.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Olivia Wang
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, with the foreign minister, Wang Yi, center, at the recent BRICS summit in Johannesburg.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The deaths of dozens of people in a fire in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Emergency vehicles and personnel surrounded the building in downtown Johannesburg.

item.title: Pope Visits Mongolia, With an Eye on Russia and China
item.description: The pontiff arrived Friday on a trip that the Vatican said was meant to encourage the fewer than 1,500 Catholics there. But it also brings him close to two great powers that have vexed him.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving at Chinggis Khaan International Airport in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, on Friday.

item.title: Could Australia and New Zealand Become One Nation?
item.description: A New Zealand lawmaker talked about the idea last week, though a union is unlikely ever to take place.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Australia flag was displayed before a Women’s World Cup soccer match in Sydney in July. Australia and New Zealand hosted the tournament.

item.title: With Robotyne Recaptured, Ukraine Takes Next Step in Counteroffensive
item.description: After penetrating Russian defenses to retake the village of Robotyne, Ukrainian forces have pushed the fight a few miles east, but formidable obstacles lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Constant Méheut and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier looking at a destroyed Ukrainian tank near the village of Robotyne last week.

item.title: Keith Spicer, Canada’s Offbeat Envoy of Reconciliation, Dies at 89
item.description: As the country’s first commissioner of official languages, he oversaw a dual-language mandate. He later led a task force to listen to Canadians’ complaints.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Fred Chartrand/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Canadian “Official Languages Commissioner” Keith Spicer speaks to reporters in 1975 about his efforts to promote a bilingual culture.

item.title: Gabon’s Leader, Ali Bongo Ondimba, Was More Admired Abroad Than at Home
item.description: Hailed as a climate visionary, Gabon’s president, Ali Bongo Ondimba, was once welcomed to Buckingham Palace but was blindsided by this week’s coup.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Dionne Searcey
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: President Ali Bongo Ondimba of Gabon and his French-born wife, Sylvia Bongo, in 2019, during celebrations marking the country’s independence from France in 1960.

item.title: Fire in Johannesburg, South Africa, Kills 74
item.description: Johannesburg, with a severe shortage of affordable housing, has hundreds of illegally occupied derelict buildings that officials and housing advocates say have become firetraps.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Outside the building in Johannesburg on Thursday. At least 12 children were among the victims.

item.title: Friday Briefing: A Deadly Fire in South Africa
item.description: Also, the U.S. resists engaging with the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: Lyna Bentahar
item.media:description: The authorities were still trying to determine the cause of the fire.

item.title: Humanity’s Ancestors Nearly Died Out, Genetic Study Suggests
item.description: The population crashed following climate change about 930,000 years ago, scientists concluded. Other experts aren’t convinced by the analysis.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Investigators Seize ‘Marcus Aurelius’ Statue From Cleveland Museum
item.description: The Manhattan district attorney’s office said the headless bronze, valued at $20 million, is a depiction of the Roman emperor and was looted from Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:description: The Cleveland Museum of Art acquired the bronze statue in 1986. The museum is now calling it “Draped Male Figure” on its website, but had earlier referred to it as a depiction of Marcus Aurelius.

item.title: VanMoof, Trendy E-Bike Brand, Bought Out of Bankruptcy by Scooter Maker
item.description: Lavoie, which makes high-end scooters based on McLaren’s Formula 1 technology, acquired the trendy e-bike brand that had gained a zealous following.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The WheelGood repair shop in Amsterdam is one of the few places where VanMoof owners could get their bikes repaired after the company declared bankruptcy.

item.title: Johannesburg Building Fire Photos: Scenes From a Deadly Blaze
item.description: The blaze struck an abandoned building that had become a crowded squatter settlement. The authorities were investigating the cause.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of a deadly blaze in downtown Johannesburg, South Africa, on Thursday.

item.title: UK Replaces Defense Secretary Ben Wallace With Grant Shapps
item.description: Mr. Wallace, a former soldier, had come to symbolize Britain’s steadfast support for Ukraine in the war against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Grant Shapps, who has been appointed as defense secretary, leaving Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Drone attacks in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleaning up in Kyiv on Wednesday after an aerial attack.

item.title: The U.S. and China Are Talking Again. Where It Will Lead Is Unclear.
item.description: Gina Raimondo, the U.S. commerce secretary, and her Chinese counterparts agreed to continue economic talks, but such dialogues have a disheartening record.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

item.title: Two Years After Afghanistan Exit, Biden Resists Calls for More Taliban Contact
item.description: Some U.S. officials had clung to the hope that the Taliban had moderated since they last controlled the country in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kabul in April. Afghanistan’s Taliban rulers have carried out revenge killings, torture and abductions, according to international observers.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Are Hit by Dueling Overnight Aerial Attacks
item.description: Four military cargo planes at a Russia airfield were damaged, and the Kyiv region was hit with one of the most significant missile and drone barrages in months.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buildings in Kyiv, Ukraine, were damaged in a drone and missile attack on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Seeks to Block Recovery of Titanic Artifacts
item.description: Washington has gone to court to become a party to the salvage case involving the famous liner so it can stop any expedition it deems objectionable.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: A view of the Titanic’s bow taken during a 2004 expedition by the remote operated vehicle Hercules to the wreckage.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Drone Attacks Reach Deep Into Russia
item.description: Also, a referendum divides Australia.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lyna Bentahar
item.media:credit: The Governor of Russian Pskov region/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Governor of Russian Pskov region Mikhail Vedernikov Telegram channel shows smoke billowing and explosions light after a drone attack in Pskov on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘Bee Emergency’: How Beekeepers Got 5 Million Bees Off a Road in Canada
item.description: A dozen beekeepers converged to help rescue a swarm of angry bees that escaped when their boxes fell off a truck in Burlington, Ontario, on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Terri Faloney, left, and Tyler Troute removing bees from a car after a truck accident in Burlington, Ontario, caused five million bees to escape from wooden boxes on Wednesday.

item.title: Canada Issues Travel Warning for L.G.B.T.Q. Citizens Visiting U.S.
item.description: Advice that travelers to the U.S. “check relevant state and local laws” came in response to rules this year restricting transgender care, drag shows and sports participation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Alicia Devine/Tallahassee Democrat, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Drag queens and allies marched to the Florida Capitol in Tallahassee in April. Moves by state lawmakers, particularly in Florida, to curtail L.G.B.T.Q. rights have received prominent attention in Canada.

item.title: A Shocking Soccer Kiss Demonstrates the Power of Scandal
item.description: By generating public outrage, scandals make inaction costly: suddenly, doing nothing carries greater risks.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales carrying a Spanish player, Athenea del Castillo, over his shoulder after the Spanish women’s world cup win in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Nigeria Arrests Dozens Over Same-Sex Wedding
item.description: A 2014 law makes such unions illegal in the country. Anyone found guilty of taking part can also face up to 10 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Some of the Nigerians being tried in 2019 on charges of public display of affection with members of the same sex. That case was later dismissed.

item.title: Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak in Poland Kills 16
item.description: Infections have surged in Rzeszow, whose strategic location near the Ukrainian border has transformed it into a hub for the Western response to Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: The market square in Rzeszow, Poland, in 2022. The health ministry said the city’s water supply was the likely source of the outbreak.

item.title: Typhoon Saola Threatens China With Category 4 Winds
item.description: The tropical cyclone was passing near Taiwan on Thursday and edging closer to Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image showing typhoon Saola moving north toward Taiwan on Tuesday.

item.title: Gabon Coup: Military Officers Seize Power From Ali Bongo
item.description: The coup was announced hours after President Ali Bongo Ondimba, whose family has controlled the country for a half-century, was declared to have been re-elected for a third term in a disputed election.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Gabon 24, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken from the Gabon 24 television channel on Wednesday showing military officers announcing that they had seized power.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Two lines of attack.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers of the 22nd Mechanized Brigade firing a self-propelled howitzer in the Bakhmut region on Monday.

item.title: Salmon Die in Droves as Climate Change Burns Canada
item.description: The effects of a summer of environmental catastrophes were felt everywhere in Canada, from its vast boreal forests to a river on Vancouver Island once fished by Hollywood royalty.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Cowichan River, on Canada’s Vancouver Island, saw hundreds of young salmon and trout die last month. The river, a renowned fly-fishing destination, is suffering from the effects of climate change, including a low water level and high water temperatures.

item.title: Macron Tries Outreach to Head Off Further Protests
item.description: After a tumultuous year, the French president is meeting with his opponents in hopes of building bridges. But few seem interested in working with him.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France has been seen as a top-down leader who rarely talks of compromise.

item.title: Parisians Want to Bring Their Neighbors Closer Together. But First, Cheese.
item.description: A grass-roots movement aims to recast urban living in Paris and other cities around the world through a hyperlocal prism of neighborliness.
item.dc:creator: Peter Yeung
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrick Bernard, the founder of the Republic of Super Neighbors in Paris, center background, with participants in the 14th arrondissement. He encourages neighbors who interact five times daily to do so 50 times a day.

item.title: Will a Bitterly Divided Australia Elevate the Aboriginal Voice?
item.description: A referendum to set up an Indigenous advisory body in Parliament was envisioned as uniting the country. The opposite has happened.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Garma Festival, the largest Aboriginal cultural gathering in Australia, in East Arnhem Land this month.

item.title: With Multiple Battles, Russia and Ukraine Puzzle Over Where to Put Troops
item.description: Russians are advancing in the Northeast, toward Kupiansk, while Ukraine presses its offensive in the South, each hoping to force the other to redeploy its forces.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers of the 22nd Mechanized Brigade firing a self-propelled howitzer in the Bakhmut region on Monday.

item.title: Rumors and Misdirection Keep Crowds Away From Prigozhin Burial
item.description: The burial of the Wagner mercenary group boss, two months after his mutiny, was shrouded in misinformation, preventing a public display of support the Kremlin did not want to see.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police and National Guard troops surrounded the Porokhovskoye cemetery in St. Petersburg, Russia, where the mercenary boss Yevgeny V. Prigozhin was buried on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: U.S. Businesses Say China Is ‘Uninvestable’
item.description: Also, a legal victory for Imran Khan.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lyna Bentahar
item.media:description: Gina Raimondo’s visit is part of an effort by the Biden administration to stop a long deterioration in the U.S. relationship with China and restore communications.

item.title: Under Uganda Anti-LGBTQ Law, Man Is Arrested on Charge Punishable by Death
item.description: Prosecutors used the death penalty provision of a newly passed law to charge a 20-year-old man. The measure has sown widespread fear among gay Ugandans.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Ugandan Parliament in May during the passage of a bill imposing severe penalties for same-sex sexual acts. It drew condemnation from human rights groups and the United Nations.

item.title: Scottish Museum Will Return Totem Pole to Nisga’a Nation in Canada
item.description: The 36-foot tall memorial pole has spent almost a century in a Scottish museum. Now it will be returned to the Nisga’a Nation in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Earl Stephens, who goes by the Nisga’a cultural name Chief Ni’is Joohl, center left, and members of a delegation from the Nisga’a nation pose beside a 36-foot tall memorial pole during a visit to the National Museum of Scotland on Monday.

item.title: Biden Discusses Migration With the President of Costa Rica
item.description: The Biden administration is working with Central American nations like Costa Rica to develop ways for migrants to apply for protection closer to their home countries.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted President Rodrigo Chaves of Costa Rica at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Factories May Be Leaving China, but Trade Ties Are Stronger Than They Seem
item.description: The United States is trying to lessen its dependence on Chinese goods, but research is showing how tough it is to truly alter global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: The United States has decreased its import of goods directly from China, but they are being funneled in through other routes.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on Rubiales Over Unwanted Kiss at World Cup
item.description: Luis Rubiales has defied calls to resign, now echoed by his own federation. Soccer’s world governing body has suspended him, and prosecutors have opened an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, Spain’s top soccer official, with members of the country’s World Cup team in Madrid last week.

item.title: Vatican Tries to Clarify Pope Francis’ Remarks on Russia
item.description: The Holy See sought to calm an outcry over comments that some critics said were too close to President Vladimir Putin’s justifications for invading Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving at his weekly general audience at the Vatican last week.

item.title: Luis Rubiales and Spain’s World Cup Kissing Scandal: What to Know
item.description: An unwanted kiss cast a pall over the Spanish team’s victory at the Women’s World Cup. Some are calling it a #MeToo moment for the country and for soccer there.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, the president of Spain’s national soccer federation, carrying Athenea del Castillo, a forward, on his shoulder after the team’s World Cup final victory in Australia this month.

item.title: In Israel’s Arab Communities, Gun Violence Surges
item.description: At least 155 Arab citizens have died this year in violence largely attributed to organized crime. Some say the government has not done enough to stop the killing.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nabil Hayek, 19, was one of four people injured in a shooting at a butcher’s shop in an Arab town in northern Israel in late July. He once had a promising future on the soccer field.

item.title: Putin Will Not Attend the Funeral for Yevgeny Prigozhin, the Wagner Chief
item.description: Details about the funeral for Yevgeny Prigozhin, who died in a plane crash last week along with nine other people, were murky.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police presence was heavy on Tuesday at the Porokhovskoye cemetery in St. Petersburg, Russia, where the press service of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin said he had been buried.

item.title: U.K. Flights to Be Disrupted for Days After Air Traffic Control Glitch
item.description: The government ruled out a cyberattack as the cause of the technical problems, which forced airlines to cancel about 5 percent of the flights in and out of the country on Tuesday as they tried to catch up.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: People waiting near check-in desks on Monday at Gatwick Airport, south of London.
